intro: Leptinella wilhelminensis, commonly known as the Wilhelmine's lepidote, is a low-growing perennial plant native to the alpine regions of South America. It belongs to the family Rosaceae and is characterized by its dense, mat-forming growth habit. The plant features small, white to pale pink flowers that bloom in spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its leaves are typically lobed and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. Leptinella wilhelminensis is adapted to harsh, high-altitude environments, thriving in well-drained soils and full sun.
